div1.p: Hench is distressed to hear about Reed's financial problems. He offers monetary assistance.

div1.head: [Draft?] of letter from Philip Showalter Hench to [Blossom Reed?], April 5, 1945
div1.p:
It would appear that neither you nor I had a very happy Christmas.
You were all alone for three days; that was too bad because Christmas of
all times is one day on which we like to share the hours with loved ones.
I lost my dear Mother on Christmas morning just before sunrise. Let me
inclose a letter which I wrote about her for some relatives and old friends.

After coming back here in January, being alone here, lonesome
without my loving family, and sorrowed by the loss of my Mother, I became
rather disspirited and I must admit I have been carrying on for about ten
weeks or so without much zest in life. But my wife and that precious little
two-year old boy of ours were able to visit me from March 3rd to 19th, and
it has helped me so much. Finally I am coming out of my mood and finding
optimism and energy to do more of the things I want to do, including getting
caught up on my correspondence.

But I know very well how you must feel, all alone with the re-
sponsibility of keeping up your home in war time with the servant scarcity,
and above all with the lonesomeness entailed by your dear Mother's absence.
I do truely hope she can be returned to you soon. Perhaps even now she and
you are together again. I have seen you two together several times and may
I remark again upon the wonderful loyalty you and your Mother have had for
each other. You have carried on with such dignity and courage.

I am distressed at what you told me about your finances. Let me
say that I felt honored that you felt you know me well enough to confide
your troubles to me. To the extent that I am able I do want to help; al-
though I have been very tardy about answering your letter, I have given it
a great deal of thought. Perhaps by now your Mother is with you again and
you can share her annuity. If not and if you still feel the way you did,
I would be interested in the silver service. I am a bit worried about the
matter. It seems so tragic that you should find it necessary to part with
it, but if you do want to, I can sympathize fully with your great desire to
put it in the hands of someone who would prize it, not just for its intrinsic
value, but for its memorable associations.

In mentioning what I am about to mention, I do hope I am not
offending you. Would it be possible, if you feel that you do want, or need,
to part with something -- would it be possible that you would rather keep
the silver service and part with a few of your Father's letters -- not the
intimate letters he wrote to your Mother before he married, not these per-
haps, but some of those from ____________? As you know, I am slowly
collecting (to save for posterity in a medical museum) every item I can
about ______ ______ ______ ______. All of those wonderful letters of his
from ______ simply must be properly preserved. They must not be lost or
even dissapated, scarttered here and there. They are of historic value and
simply must be preserved in a proper manner.

Perhaps I am suggesting something which is distasteful to you.
If so, please do forgive me, but if you do wish them to be preserved for
a medical museum, I would be very grateful and proud to be the curator.
I hate even to use the words “sell them”, but assuredly they should carry
a monetary value as well as a historical value, and I would certainly be
delighted to have the opportunity. Perhaps you would prefer to consider
parting with a few rather than the collection -- or even only one or two.
From the historical standpoint the New Year's Eve letter is one which
should be preserved in the medical museum.

Were you to consider preserving some or many of the letters, I
would be only too glad not only to see to it that they were preserved for
posterity, first in the Mayo Clinic collection, later in the ______ ______
Museum I still hope to establish, but I would be delighted to arrange to
have every letter -- every page -- photostated for you so that you could
still have copies of the complete set in case you wish later to finish
your article about your Father.

I do most sincerely hope my making this suggestion has not dis-
turbed you. How can one set a price on the letters, or even on one letter.
Perhaps, indeed, you prefer to part with the silver service.

May I be frank enough to ask one thing. Will your brother be
disturbed if you part with either the silver service or the letters? Does
he consider them in part his or are they wholely yours? Your brother has,
of course, the greatest possible pride in your Father and his wonderful
work and he might consider it improper to allow these items to leave the
family, even though they were to be preserved by loving and respectful
strangers. I do not want to do anything which he would consider as taking
advantage of your situation. Is it not possible that your situation may
be only very temporary and that you might not need to part with anything?
I would be only too glad to lend you the amount you suggested if that would
help.

I know this is a delicate matter for you to discuss and, indeed,
I find it difficult to write this as it just doesn't seem right for you to
be put in this position, but you have honored me with your friendship and
your confidence and I do so much want to be of service. Please do forgive
me for answering your letter so tardily. I hope my delay has not permitted
you to think me unsympathatic or disinterested. I shall be happy to hear
from you very soon and I do so hope the difficulty is over. Also that your
Mother is well enough to come back to your home to be with you. If she is
well enough, that certainly is where she would be happiest.

I am so glad that you like the ______ _______ stamps. Mother
was happy to be able to share with me the pleasure of sending them to you
and your Mother. We had talked about it before she became so ill and she
had asked me to try to get some for you, therefore, they were from her in
fact and not just in name. My Mother became so interested in the stories
of the ______ ______ ______ ______. She read everything I could get
on the matter. I showed her a few of the letters you so kindly loaned
me and she was so greatly facinated, as she, too, had a high sense of
their value to history.

I miss Mother terribly and I am very proud of the heritage she
and my Father left us. They were wonderful Christians; the kind that is
seen rarely in these troubled days. How very much my Mother would have
enjoyed meeting you and your Mother and brother.

closer.seg: P.S. I will send you a check at once if you need it.
